comments.text: hi, whatever i do, i just can't get this print right. even with a raft, max fan, and just 30, 20, 10 (fill, inner shell, outer shell) speed, the back part always curls up (the bottom stays on the plate). have you printed this on the overlord? if so, then what kind of sorcery are you utilizing?
comments.author: partychoke

comments.text: No magic, I used PLA, no raft no skirt, stock cura settings. Make sure you have good bed adhesion as there is not much touching the bed. The OL's have a useless autolevel system that does not take into account for Delta_Radius adjustments. So printing closer to the side of the build platforms usually gets better adhesion. I use "Disapearing Purple" glue stick on the bed as well.
comments.author: partychoke

comments.text: thanks, but mine sticks to the bed as well, but as the print goes ahead, the upper layers of the curvy back part curl up, and the nozzle then squishes them, it's like they are not cooling fast enough. i don't know what to do.
comments.author: Av8er

comments.text: What type of filiment are you using? What are your settings for this? If the layers are splitting apart you might need to raise the temperature of the extruder.  If it's just curling but not splitting you might be too hot.
comments.author: partychoke

comments.text: hi, thanks for the advice, but i've already read that. i'm using pla, and as it turns out, insufficient cooling was the problem, because i've just printed a modified fan duct, and with that installed, your piece printed perfectly, and it fits greatly, so i'm going to bed happy tonight :)

title: Taylored Bahtinov mask - Parametric OpenScad file including the "Bahtinov factor" - Masks for William Optics GTF81 and MAK Intes Micro M603

description.text:
Masque de Bahtinov entièrement paramétrique, permettant de configurer un pasque "sur mesure" pour lunette ou télescope, avec ou sans obstruction centrale, de type "bouchon" ou non.
La largeur et l'espacement des fentes sont calculées en fonction de la focale de l'optique et du "facteur de Bahtinov".
Une fiche d'instruction contient la description des variables.

Fully parametric Bahtinov mask, that allows "tailored" masks for telescopes with or without central obstruction, with or without "cap" shape.
Gorrve width and step are calculated according to the focal length and the "Bahtinov factor".
An instruction sheet contains the signification of the parameters.

Deux masques sont proposés à titre d'exemples :
Two masks are proposed as examples :

  • William Optics GTF81
  • MAK Intes Micro M603
    (they fit two of my telescopes).

author: Triumpher

description.text:
Word clock kit.

Inspired by the two tutorials by drj113 at www.instructables.com:
http://www.instructables.com/id/The-Wordclock-Grew-Up
http://www.instructables.com/id/The-Word-Clock-Arduino-version/

To build this you will need 8 M3 screws, zip ties to secure the led strips and glue to secure the diffusers. The top of the case two holes for two 12mm push buttons to adjust the time.

For the electronic part, follow the supplied tutorials but bear in mind that if you want to use the four leds on the bottom to display the minutes you will have to modify the code supplied by drj113, as I'm still waiting for all the bits to assemble this I have yet to start messing with the code.

Print the case and back cover with dark filament to stop light bleeding trough. The diffusers should be printed with transparent or translucent filament. Place a drop of glue on the sides of the diffusers before inserting them in the corresponding slots on the case. The loose parts of the letters (o, r and a) use the diffusers to attach to the case so use a drop of glue on them before inserting them.

Secure the led strips with zip ties to the light support. Route the cables to the back using the supplied holes. Place the light support in the case.

Secure the electronics to the electronic support. Zip ties should do the job, but the spacing between the bars allows for m3 screws if you prefer to use them.
For the four leds on the bottom use a drop of glue to secure them to the support or use sleeving on the leds and simply twist the legs on the back of the support.
Use four m3 screws to attach the electronics support to the case.

Insert two 12mm push buttons in the two corresponding holes in the top of the case, and connect them to your electronics.

For power simply pass the charger cable trough the hole in the back cover and connect it to you electronics (probably an arduino).

Place the back cover over the case and secure it with four m3 screws.

Connect it to the mains, ajust the time and enjoy it.

comments.text: "The loose parts of the letters (o, r and a) use the diffusers to attach to the case"

description.text:
Mount to hold a Mitutoyo micrometer head to use as the adjustable z-axis endstop.   
Also includes the lower mount for the switch and rod clamp to hold it to a 10mm rod.

The micrometer head holder is designed to hold a Mitutoyo 148-811 micrometer head to a MendelMax 1.5 build using Lulzbot X-ends. It'll probably hold many other micrometer heads.  You'll probably have to clean out the hole to fit the micrometer to achieve a snug assembly fit. Tap the side hole for a 4/40 set screw to hold the micrometer head in place.   
I've included the Solidworks files for your modification pleasure.

Disclaimer: This is a work in progress, I uploaded the stl so I have a place where I can document the progress. Do not print yet. I will make multiple stl's available so you can print groups of parts.

This is a remix of the awesome Plot clock / thermometer designed by smily77.

I had trouble getting the hinge apart from the main body and since smily77 was so nice to share the source for the body on tinkercad I took a shot and adjusted it to my needs.

I reworked it in a way so that the hinge can be mounted with M3 screws. Also all needed parts may now be printed without support.
I removed the holder for the magnet, since my 3d printed drawing board just stands in place without any additional help.
The whole thing may now be parametrized, so you can easily adapt the design to your servos and your printers tolerances.

This thing is split into several part groups which may be printed together.
You will also find an open scad file which allows you to make adjustments to the model to fit your servo and your printers tolerances with holes.

Printing:

I highly recommend printing the parts in the following order:

  1. plot_clock-group_sweeper.stl: This group should print in less than half an hour and contains a part with an M3 hole. You can use this hole to verify that your printers tolerancies are in sync with the model. If the M3 screw fits through the hole fine, or only requires a little filing, you are good to go.

  2. plot_clock-group_arms.stl: The Plot clocks arms. Make sure that M3 screws fit through all the holes loosely, otherwise drill or file them to size. Make sure the pen fits into the holder.
    Check that the servo horns fit into the cut outs in two of the arms.

  3. plot_clock-group_hinge.stl: The hinge housing the drawing servos. Make sure your servos slide in nicely and stay in place without too much play. Also make sure that a M3 screw fits loosely into the hinges arm.
    Check that the cover slides on nicely.
    Check that a M3 screw screws nicely into the connector element.

  4. [plot_clock-group_body.stl](): The plot clocks main body. Make sure that the servo fits nicely into the center piece. Make sure the center piece slides into the body snugly.
    Check that a M3 screw fits through the outer ring of the arms and screws tightly into the inner hole of the arms - do this on both sides.
    Make sure that you can screw a M3 screw into the sweeper hole of the main body.

Preparing the Electronics

Attach cables to VCC, GND, SDA and SCL on the real time clock. Do not connect them to the Arduino yet.

Next build a power and signal distribution board on a small piece of proto port. Attach a cable for 5V, GND and to each each signal pin.
Do not attach to the Arduino yet. 

GND ---+-+-+  
 5V ---+-+-+  
SIG    + + +  
       | | |

Insulate the contacts on the bottom with some tape.

Attach 2 cables to your switch. One needs to be short since it only has to go to GND of the power jack, the other one needs to be long enough to reach the Arduino.

Assembly and Calibration

  1. Mount one of the servos to the center body piece so that the servos axle is furthest away from the hole in the center piece.

  2. Attach the hinge to the main body with 2 M8x8mm screws. Make sure the hinge moves easily. You may need to file the bodys inner arms and the hinges arms down a little bit.
    I filed them down a little bit until they fitted in smoothly, put in the screws and manually opened and closed the hinge a couple of times until it moved freely.

  3. Insert the remaining two servos in a way so that their axles are next to each other. Route the servo cables through the hinges hole and into the body.

  4. Insert the bodys center part into the main body part with the servo axle next to the cut out in the body.

  5. Mark the servo cables at their connectors so you know which one is for which. I marked them on the signal cable like so:
    1 Line: left servo
    2 Lines: lift servo
    3 Lines: right servo

  6. slide the hinge cover onto the hinge. Make sure it is flat on the hinge, press it down a little bit if needed.

  7. Take your zip ties, and tie the servo cables together so the connectors are all more or less on one height. Do not tie them to strong yet, so you have a little place for adjusting.

  8. Hook up the wires from the power and signal distribution board to the Arduino.
    VCC, GND
    Pin 2: lift servo
    Pin 3: left servo
    Pin 4: right servo

  9. Mount the switch in the main body and attach its signal wire to Arduino Pin 6

  10. Attach the RTC to the Arduino, SDA to A4 and SCL to A5.

  11. Wire up all the power lines to the DC jack and mount the DC jack in the main body. You will have to check your power supply to make sure which is VCC and which is GND.
    Usually the pin on the end of the jack will be VCC and the one on the side of the jack GND. I had an additional GND pin on my jack on the bottom, which i just snipped of.

  12. After everything is hooked up we are ready to move on with setting the RTC, as described below. If your RTC is already set, you can skip to the next step.

  13. Attach the height arm to one of the servo horns with a screw. Make sure the arm moves freely on this screw. Then attach the height arm to the hinge with an M3x8mm screw. Make sure the height arm moves freely.

  14. With the RTC calibrated and the height arm in place we can now start the plotters main calibration as described in the paragraph below.

  15. After we are done with the calibration we can now fully attach the arms.

  16. Insert the remaining two servo horns into the upper Servo Arms. You may want to glue them in place for a good fit.

  17. Wire the electronics (Part 1): Put the power distribution and signal board

  18. Initial Calibration: Flash the TBD.ino onto your arduino

Setting the RTC

Install the Time library and the DS1307RTC library.

Fire up the Arduino IDE and from File->Examples->Time choose TimeRTCSet and upload the code to your Arduino.
Open the serial monitor and you should see output like this: 

Unable to sync with the RTC  
0:00:00 0 0 1970

Now open your console and set the time accordingly. For UTC type: 

date +T%s > /dev/ttyUSB0

If you are in another timezone than UTC you will need to account for the offset to UTC for yourself. For example UTC+2 would be: 

echo T$(($(date +%s) + 3600 * 2)) > /dev/ttyUSB0

In the serial monitor you should now see the accurate time. You can verify that the RTC is working by unplugging the Arduino, plugging it back in and check the serial monitor which should now print the current time.

Plotter calibration

Fire up your Arduino IDE and upload TBD.ino to your arduino.

  • Open the serial monitor and type x to enter Setup mode

  • Type A to load default calibration values

  • Type 5, this will move the lift servo in its drawing position, attach the height arms servo horn to the lift servo, so that the hinge is in its drawing position. In case the servo summs, use + and - until it stops.

  • Type 6, this will move the lift servo in its pen half way up position. Use + and - until the hinge is approximately at a ten degree angle.

  • Type 7, this will move the lift servo in its pen up position. Use + and - until the hinge is approximately at a twenty degree angle.

  • Type B to save your current calibration. You can now verify that the height arm is working properly by checking with 5,6 and 7.

BOM

This is a list of additional materials you will need:

  • 3x mini servo
  • Small piece of proto board
  • 3x3x1 pin headers
  • Arduino pro mini
  • DC Jack
  • Switch
  • some wire
  • 5V power supply
  • Real time clock
  • 2 M3x8mm Screws
  • some zip ties

I recently decided to go through all of my ukuleles and replace the synthetic nuts and saddles with bone ones. After going through two of them, my fingers are just in too much pain from shaping them from blanks. I know belt sanders can be had for $40 these days but I just wanted a small sander to work with these nuts and saddles.

So I designed this little Dremel (mine is a Dremel 300-1) holder and table to do just this with a grinding stone or sanding band adapter. And it works great!

Be sure to print the table upside down to keep the top of table as flat as possible. The Cura screenshot will show my settings but I might up the infill a bit. I designed this so there's really not much pressure on the structure while sanding (since you're pushing against the Dremel and not onto the table or stand) so mine works fine in PLA.
Print 2 of the hubs and one of the threaded rod. It fits spools with diameters of 25mm to 70mm. The rod hole fits 9mm rods. I made this for my Rigidbot but it would work on other printers as well.

Here is a simple bowl based on a 50 electron solution to the Thomson problem. http://www-wales.ch.cam.ac.uk/~wales/CCD/Thomson/table.html Decorations are hidden inside the bowl and are meant to show the importance of "five" in duals to the Thomson solutions. Six pentagons occur around the circumference of the bowl and are decorated with pentagrams; the lid shows a large "Cinquefoil Knot". OpenSCAD code is included.

The bowl and lid can be printed without support. On my Replicator I used 0.3 mm levels and 2 shells. The "Cinquefoil Knot" comes from Kit Wallace's "Knots to openscad" - http://kitwallace.co.uk/3d/knot.xq -

Light up the night with this simple and smart night light!

Harnessing the brains of a dirt cheap ESP8266 WiFi Module, this networkable, super bright APA106/WS8212 LED runs all night off 2 rechargeable LIR2032 lithium ion coin cells. All day 3 solar cells work to recharge the batteries through the help of a DC voltage boost converter and diode.

The best part...it'll only run you in the neighborhood of $10 !!!

This is certainly not your average solar garden light!

Programming Guide Video:
http://youtu.be/IudpebSy960
(sorry currently uploading)

LightItUp! #lightitup #LightItUp

Parts you'll need:
-ESP8266 Wifi Module
-40x15mm 1v mini solar cell (x3)
-LIR2032 rechargeable coin cell (x2)
-LM1117 SOT-223 5v and 3.3v regulators
-APA106 F8 8mm Led
-5v .3 A mini SPDT slide switch
-DC step up converter or "Jewel Thief" (i used a 6W 2v-6v to 12v step up but any with an output higher than 7.2v will work fine)
-1N4148 Diode or any generic diode
-small screws ( i used standard computer/hard drive size screws)
-little bits of scrap wire

Tools:
-3.3v USB Serial Console Cable or logic level converter
-wire strippers
-soldering equipment
-jumper wires (and breadboard helps)
-super glue or hot glue
-heatshrink and/or electrical tape
-3d Printer

Each part can be found on ebay for less than a couple dollars, or even cents each.

Printing:
All parts print without support material! Settings arent too critical, just make sure to have your extrusion rate properly calibrated to make all of the curves. A bit slower and more precise speed setting is definitely recommended.
There are 4 parts, the main body, top cap/bonnet, bottom plate, and battery strap/clip. Original designed cadd files included for your convenience.

Wiring:
The wiring Diagram is attached and it is definitely will take a bit of wiggling to get things settled inside, but I recommend soldering nice long leads to each component first, the gluing and/or just placing the components in place, and then finally trimming to length and soldering together the final connections. Be sure to use enough heatshrink and E-tape to cover up all exposed metal to prevent any accidental shorts.

!!!ATTN: CHANGE ON WIRING DIAGRAM!!!
MUST ADD 100 ohm or 220 ohm RESISTOR BETWEEN ESP AND Din of LED

Cool Tech:
The ESP8266 is a really cool chip, because not only is it dirt cheap, but it also has a pretty powerful built in processor and can be wired into the LED directly using a one wire protocol, the same as a WS8212 led, eliminating the need for an additional in between microcontroller.

The only snafu is that the ESP runs on 3.3v logic but the APA106 led runs on 5v logic. Therefore we will need 2 voltage regulators for each voltage. I originally thought I was going to need a logic level shifter to convert the 3.3v signal from the ESP to the 5v signal the LED needs, but it turns out the APA106 works perfectly fine without it so we don't need one after all.

Programming:
Chip:
To program the ESP8266 module we can actually use the super popular free Arduino IDE to upload our code.

Here is a really awesome tutorial I found on how to setup programming an ESP8266 Module and more:

https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-huzzah-esp8266-breakout/using-arduino-ide

and

https://learn.adafruit.com/esp8266-temperature-slash-humidity-webserver
(you can also get an inexpensive DHT-11 sensor and make a cool wifi weather stat with the same parts!)

I highly recommend searching around Adafruit's Learning System if you are relatively new to the world of DIY electronics as they have alot of really great stuff.

Web App:

For the application to control the light I used Web2Py which is a fully web-based python full-stack framework and development environment. In layman's terms it is basically a swiss army knife of web developing bundles.

You can get started programming your own websites in about half an hour following Mike Herman's Web2Py Crash Course Lessons:

http://mherman.org/blog/2012/11/27/crash-course-in-web2py-part-1/#.VbMHr5NViko

I folllowed the lessons from knowing absolutely nothing about web programming and made a pretty decent app from it in no time! He also shows you how to host your app on your very own cloud for free using www.pythonanywhere.com

Here is my app for your viewing pleasure:
https://car9matt.pythonanywhere.com/wifireflyte/default/blink

My app is still in its infancy but it gets the job done. It cycles through 5 colors you can set, and allows you to control the fade speed. More features to come in the future.

For it to work both your light and mobile device have to on the same wifi network. You will get error messages while messing around with my app because it will fail to find a connection. The app passes arguments to the ESP module as a web client using URLs, just like typing your favorite website address into your internet search bar.

PACKED WEB2PY APP AND ARDUINO CODE NOW UPLOADED IN DOWNLOADS SECTION!!!

Super quick web2py start:

  1. Go To http://www.web2py.com/init/default/download
  2. Download and unzip appropriate install package for your system.
  3. In unzipped folder open "Web2py.exe"
  4. When GUI window pops up enter any password then "Start Server"
  5. A window should now open in your browser, this is web2py's programming and operating environment, it is all run in-browser. Click "admin" and enter the password you made up before. This is where you edit your programs.
  6. On the right side go to Upload Application select the .w2p file you downloaded from this thingiverse thing and give it whatever name you want. Hit okay and wait until it saves.
  7. From the admin "editing" page if you click on the app you just named it will open the app. To edit the app click on manage > edit. Go to controllers > default > edit and enter the serverURL ip address that the arduino program gave you in the serial window. (more arduino installation instructions in arduino .ino file)
  8. Now open the app as explained in step 7. and viola! It should work. If it gives you error messages whenever you click on things that means it doesnt have a connection to the ESP8266. Make sure you have the right server ip address in the web2py program, and also make sure your ESP8266 is connecting to the internet by checking the Arduino Serial Monitor. Turning the ESP board On and Off usually will get it to reconnect. Remember, you also must be on the same wifi!

Most Importantly please check out the tutorials on the links above, as they can explain so much more that I simply do not have the space to go over here!

The arduino code is pretty well commented and has install instructions in it. Also looking at the ESP8266 Adafruit Tutorial linked above is a MUST!

Worst case you are having trouble with web2py the arduino code defaults to a pretty rainbow mode!

Wrap-Up:
The potential for this light is limitless! It truly has infinite number of uses and can create the most exciting light shows you can dream of! As long as you can figure how how to program it of course :)

The WiFireflyte has tons of potential for expansion too! Design new bases, hooks and hangars, put additional charging and programming ports, develop killer Android and iOS apps, even networking between multiple units for crazy light shows! Most importantly...

JUST HAVE FUN WITH IT!!!!

Thanks and I hope you enjoy!
-Matt

title: LED Sticks: A Modular, Low Power, LED Light System for 3D Printers #LightItUp

description.text:
As someone who prints a lot, and who rarely sleeps, I would always find myself using my cell phone light to look at my prints while working through the night. I was so tired of it I designed a basic LED driver that operates from a wall outlet, to provide visible light while printing.

As my designs kept evolving I finally settle on having a main driver unit(shown clipped onto the top left, printed in brown) with multiple clip-on LED "sticks" which you can stick on any edge of 3D printers. I had my circuit fabricated, and began prototyping. The current design can feature up to 8 Modular LED sticks, with just the change of a small resistor. I used bendable cables for wiring up the LEDs, and then covered them with clear cable protectors to ensure they could take a beating, as well as look stylish. As you'll see these are not your typical LEDs, but LEDs used for back-lighting and aesthetic design purposes. I will have a link soon to provide where I purchased them.

As you'll see in the pictures, I used kapton tape to secure the LED onto the stick itself. This method allows the user to use any type of colored tape to get the light tone they want. Kapton tape is semi-orange and gives off a "warm" white versus a bright white. I used BSI gap-filler to secure the wire leads onto the stick, for a firm super glue like hold.

Using a caliper, I was able to make precise measurements to make sure that the clips will not interfere with the printing process. So far there are no problems! The LED driver PCB is shown as the last picture with a basic description, please let me know if you have questions, I am planning on posting the schematic and parts list soon.

Last but not least, you'll find 3 .stl files provided. The driver case, and two different LED Stick sizes, regular and "Jumbo." They are very basic and easy designs for quick printing and use. I designed this project to grow, feel free to message me if you are interested in the LED driver unit, I have plenty :)

LED DRIVER: After bread-boarding basic circuit designs I settled on a driver design. I used Eagle PCB Layout software to route the components to export as Gerber files, and then order basic fabrication PCBs.

LED STICK: I wanted something you could move around, and work without using any moving parts, I got the "clip" idea from a previous chip-clip design of mine. As for the shape I waned to have an easily printable geometric shape.

comments.text: Driver unit... So does that driver operate on 110 volts? What kind of LEDs work for this?
comments.author: phrogg111

comments.text: The Driver takes in 12VDC, generally LEDs will turn on at ~3V, so 12/3 = 4 LEDs, plus add in a resistor,which is why I have 3 LEDs for mine. The driver can take in a larger voltages (say 24VDC) and you could easily power 8 LEDs. To get that 12VDC onto the board I just bought a cheap power adapter (plugs into 110VAC, spits out 12VDC) with a current draw max at 1A. I will post a picture of the whole setup as well as a schematic for the board. USB is typically 5VDC, and as long as your LEDs arent "color changing" or high power they should work. Let me know if this helps
comments.author: phrogg111

If the model is super tiny when you open it up in the slicer, just change the scale from mm to cm (multiply by 10). Be sure to rotate the model so it is sitting on the cup, like in the first picture. That way, no supports are needed. A raft will help though.

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 or finer

15%

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lzToQvKOxi1
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/76YsWF2RO90

This was my first go at a Vertical Axis Wind Turbine (VAWT). I've made a 'Mk2' now that you can find here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:948401

These caught my interest when I saw one and realised that I couldn't explain why it worked.

I wouldn't recommend that anyone prints it as it uses a heap of plastic and there's about a dozen things that I wished that is done differently. On top of that there's been no wind so I haven't a clue whether it works!

I'm in the middle of designing the "Mk2" which will have a fair bit more thought go into it. Once I get this bit going I'll start having a think about what I can get it to do.

I really wish there was a bit of wind at the moment; I'd quite like to see if it spins.

The print was done in two halves that were aligned with dowels and glued (thought the alignment didn't work as well as I'd hoped.

I haven't given much thought to the mounting yet. This just uses a couple of roller-blade bearings push-fit into the mount which itself sits in the hole in the base / top.

This is an aeroguard for alpinedrones' awesome unibody quad.

V2 has a cutout for the flight controller and clips on to the top of the standoffs. Also, the FPV camera hole has been made larger for more tilt.

I have added a new thick 1mm version, same as V2 but thicker and sturdier.

Thick version notes:

  • You can have use infill and more perimeters
  • There is an extra tab layer in the rear that needs to be trimmed. It's there to supplement adhesion and prevent warping while printing

Recommended instructions (v1 and v2):

  • Use round 35mm standoffs
  • Print using a stiff plastic that doesn't warp, like PLA
  • Use a .4mm nozzle (walls are .4mm thick)
  • Print with .2mm layer height, 1 perimeter, and no infill
  • Use a brim if necessary to stay upright, although not really needed
  • Tested using the latest Slic3r stable build

Note: I did not test with a hex type standoff, let me know if you have any issues

This is a compilation of three pieces I found in other spool hub designs on this site, plus a plug I made (scad included).

Print 2 hub inserts, and your choice of 2 knobs and/or plugs.

Hub inserts can have 608zz bearing inserted and held on 8mm thread-rod with knob+nut.

I prefer to use knob+nut, shimmed with washers - glued into hub directly (no bearing) and a second hub insert with plug+nut (again glued). 8mm thread-rod w/ spool affixed tightly, spins free-floating on my a-frame filament stand.

Printed at .25mm layer height, using ABS. Supports may be needed for hub insert - I use KISSlicer Pro 1.5 Beta (has very nice support options).
Glue I used is ABS slurry. Gorilla glue can be used if printing PLA.

Disclaimer: I collected most of these from others I found on this site - any rights belong to the original author (and their terms defined).

v is often seen on clocks representing 5
The letter V comes from the Semitic letter Waw
Peace and hope "Romans 5"
v is the 22nd letter of the English alphabet.

In Roman numerals, the letter 'V' is used to represent the number 5. It was used because it resembled the convention of counting by notches carved in wood, with every fifth notch double-cut to form a 'V'.

Perseus (Greek: ΠΕΡΣΕΥΣ) is inscribed as ΠΕΡΣΕVΣ (from right to left), using V to represent the vowel [u].

In the International Phonetic Alphabet, /v/ represents the voiced labiodental fricative.

There was an oldsmodile v5,,,
A helicopter v5 in the late 1950's

So v = 5

description.text: Remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2257
I just duplicated, dragged and dropped a Mobius strip.

Updated 8/10/15:
I remade the shroud due to the tip warping by being too close to the nozzle.

This is a fan shroud to use a 40mm fan on a Rostock Max V2. It is the most compact I could make it and should clear the arms all the way out to the printers build area. It sits only a few mm above the standard nozzle. It should be printed in ABS. It is a tight fit on the fan mounts, but that way it doesn't move while the printer is going and you probably don't have to use a screw to hold it on.
Do not print in PLA or it will warp. I printed in ABS, zero infill. 2 layers top and bottom, 2 perimeters.

I have made a model of a sculpture from my hometown. Please find the pictures of the creation stages. The sculpture placed at the riverbank is more than 2 meters high (6'6") so it was not easy to to make a 123D Catch capture. I had to take 70 photos and to use manual stitching to produce good capture. Here the capture in 123D site: http://www.123dapp.com/catch/Captain/4085228
60Mb maximum resolution mesh was edited with Blender. I cleanded up the mesh a little bit and added a cylindrical base for the figurine.
I used Slic3r to slice the model and my Prusa i3 to print it in translucent PLA. The figurine is about 10cm (4") height, It's complex geometry made it very hard to remove all the support material without damage anything. I used sandpaper to clean the figurine and painted it with acrylics.
You can see the result. Hope you like it.

title: Mini Sumo with Remote Control
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I modified the SketchUp Mini Sumo. The motor holder is much stronger. On my prints the original one always broke due to bad layer bonding. The chassis has holes for 5x7cm proto pcb with M2 stand up and screws. There are also holes for a 2AA battery holder to use two 14500 LiPo. There is also an option to mount a 500mAh-800mAh 2S-LiPo with JST connector.

The blade now can fixed with only two M3 screws an nuts. There is also a hole for a small switch.

The transmitter was made of an old Nintendo controller.

I will post the Arduino code and schematics within the next weeks. Please be patient.

Update:

Still working on schematics.
Added source code for bot and remote. Code is ugly but works :)

Partlist:

Both (Remote control and robot):

  1. Arduino pro min 3.3V 8MHz
  2. nRF24L01 Module 2.4GHz RF transceiver

Robot:

  1. DRV8835 Dual Motor Driver Carrier from Pololu
  2. Micro Metal Gearmotor from Pololu or similar. 6V 1:50 Gear Ratio and Medium Power (about 700mA Stall Current) is quit fast and makes a lot of fun.
  3. Lipo options: 2x 14500 Lipo with an 2xAA holder or a about 600mAh 2S Lipo

Remote:

  1. an old Nintendo NES oder SNES will work fine.
  2. I used nRF24l01 transceiver with uFL connector and an small 2.4GHz antenna. A transceiver with pcb antenna works fine and has enough range for indoor.
  3. very small Lipo from small quadcopters or similar
  4. some very thin wires i.e. AWG26 or 28

title: The rotating flowers - a small lights collection

description.text:
The night flower , the down flower , the morning flower and the noon flower compose The rotating flowers - a small lights collection !!
Each flower is composed by :

  • a corolla of one, two or three rings , rotating independently, so you can compose or change different forms
  • a base with foliage
  • a battery small light ( not 3d printed )

remixed_from.author: enif
remixed_from.title: Flexing battery holders with integrated spring

title: Flexing battery holders with 2- and 3-cell compartments

description.text:
Thingiverse user pcoulbourne asked me if I could extend my flexing battery holders with integrated spring project to also support multi-cell compartments which house 2 or 3 cells in series and are held with a single plastic spring.

With more than one cell in a row the pushing force of the spring is prone to lift the batteries up at their joining point and push them out of the compartment. Also longer cells are more prone to cause warping. The solution to these problems was to add cutouts at the center of each cell to allow a better grip when manipulating the cells (and thereby reducing the warping!) and add an inside overhang between the cutouts to prevent the batteries from popping out.

The included fully parametrized SCAD file is an extension to the initial version, thus it can as well be used to generate all the single cell compartment battery holders from the initial project. However, the STLs included here are only the ones with 2- and 3-cell compartments for some of the more common cell types. I started by including ready-to print STLs for AA, AAA, C and 18650 type cells, others might follow. But of course you can easily generate multi-cell holders for any other cell type yourself by adding the corresponding module calls in the OpenScad source file.

Note that when having 2 or 3 cells secured by a single plastic spring, even small variations of the cell length may become critical, since the differences are dupli- or triplicated. Small differences can be compensated to some extent by varying the thickness of the pole contacts.

I suggest to load and unload the batteries from the plus end of the compartment (opposite side of the spring) and slide the cells there as showing in one of the pictures. Pushing the batteries through the overhang generates stress on the side walls of the case, especially for the smaller cells.

For any further details, please check out the initial version of this project.

I printed these battery holders on my DIY box-frame Prusa i3 using a 0.40mm nozzle with 0.25mm layer height and 0.56mm extrusion width. I print on a clear mirror without Kapton tape but thoroughly cleaned with acetone and double concentrated lemon juice.

The contacts for the plus and minus pole can easily be made by a few windings of the uninsulated ends of the connecting wires. The windings can be made into a more solid pole contact by applying quickly (!) a bit of solder to join the windings. The outside of the wire windings at the plus pole can be electrically isolated by a few drops of ABS/acetone slur of the same color.

By default, the thickness of the spring part is twice the extrusion width ew. If you have a significantly different extrusion width, for obtaining optimal spring strength, you might want to modify the eh and ew parameters in the SCAD file to fit your printer, and then regenerate the STLs you need.

comments.text: Thanks for your remarks.  Speaking for myself, except for the very small AAA type cells, I never had any problems winding the contact wires around the contact cylinders. I usually tin the first 2-3cm of the stripped contact wire so it gets stiff and can be used like a needle.  The problem with the small cells is not the winding of the contact wire, but to get the wire between the two halves of the integrated spring. So I then use some sort of "spacer" to spread the spring halves apart to facilitate inserting the wire.

comments.text: Essentially, it's just the parameter m which controlls the number of cells in one compartment, so if you use the same parameters to call flexbatter() as are in flexbatterCR123A(), but with m=2, you should get a battery holder for 2 CR123A in a row. title: XQ Tricopter Yaw (Motor Tilt) Mechanism (12mm aluminum booms)

description.text: This is my solution that I use in my tricopter.

BOM for just the tilt:

  • 8x5x3 bearings (you need two)
  • M5 square nut
  • M5 nut
  • M5 60mm screw
  • 10g servo (I used metal gear digital)
  • zip tie
  • some kind of no-play linkage of choice (search for ball joints)
  • levers (I cnc routed mine out of 1.5mm glass laminate, just as motor mounts)
  • printed parts (I used PLA, ABS will work just as well)

Note: I used thread lock on M5 after preloading the bearings.

you can also see my own super-sexy engine mounts that I cnc routed.

author: friedmanwd

title: Crocz... Crocodile Clips / Clamps / Pegs with Moving Jaws
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Crocz have moving jaws that bite... they're great for clips, pegs and a bit of fun. This is a quick and easy print. There are two versions... one without designed in support (i.e. no support necessary) and one with designed-in support where required.

(1) The 'Crocz' file version has legs that protrude out the sides so there is designed in supports for this that should peel away easily after printing freeing the jaws to start snapping.

(2) The alternative 'Crocz - no support' file' has straight/flat sides with recesses to represent the shape of the legs. This will print faster and is the file to use if you are concerned about the designed in support slicing/printing well for you.

(3) As some people requested the version with legs (so requiring support for the legs) without any designed in support this has been added. However, only use this if you are experienced at adding your own support. Using automated support can build in support that will stop the jaws from moving and will be difficult to remove. My recommendation is to use the designed in support... it surprises most people by how well it works!

Refer to the instructions and images for additional print information...

Also check out my other similar designs:

'Bugz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1904654

'Minisaurs' https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476792

'Z-REX' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1594269

'Ratz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1532944

'Woodpeckerz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1155168

'Sharkz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:910216

'Eaglez' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:963892

'Catz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:988088

'Scorpionz' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001286

Note: If you like these check out the rest of my designs!

The 'Crockz - no support' .stl file does not require any support but the same shells and fill as below apply.

The necessary support has been designed into the 'Crocz' .stl file. On a well set up machine the support should peel away easily if printed according to the following settings.

Printed with PLA
Raft not essential but recommended
Standard / 0.20mm resolution
3 or 4 shells
60-75% infill (varying this will affect how springy your Crocz are)
No support required... it's designed in on the 'Crocz' file and not required on the 'Crocz - no support' file.

Scaling up/down is not recommended as it will affect the clearances of the designed in support (Which is necessary for the legs that come out the side of the body)

comments.author: BiznisKitty

comments.text: That is an issue with Raft... it leaves an air gap between the top surface of the Raft and base of the Print itself. That's why it breaks away as the air gap creates a weak point but also compromises quality / finish. Think of it this way, as the filament is extruder with too much clearance it starts cooling / solidifying then hits the Raft surface below... it's sticky enough to bond to the Raft for the rest of the print to print well but weak enough to break away.

comments.text: Pleased to hear you like my Crocz.... with most machines this shouldn't be an issue but you are right, not all filament prints as well as other filament. title: Geeetech I3 pro 8mm Acrylic X, Y pully guide

description.text:
Please see below update
When the X, Y pulley are not centered correctly, the belt slowly moves to one side till it gets stuck and then your lose your print.

Update:

I have found the ball bearing that fits the printer belt.
http://www.banggood.com/GT2-Synchronous-Wheel-3MM-Without-Teeth-For-3D-Printer-Accessories-p-1013245.html?p=9R09143243493201512Z
You will need 2 screws from bag #27 ( M3x20mm ), and 2 Hex Lock nut from bag #13 ( Hex Socket nuts M3 ). There is not enough in the printer bag, so you can also get them at:
http://www.banggood.com/10pcs-Carbon-Steel-Self-Locking-Hex-Nut-Nylon-Insert-Lock-Nut-M2M2_5M3M4M5M6M8-p-1007119.html?p=9R09143243493201512Z
chose M3.

it works great.

At list 5 pcs should be printed. when you assemble them, if one of them brakes, you have another spare.
The diameter is a tight fit, so you need to push the baring in and it should be flat with the table and the baring.

My 40mm 12V fan sucked at cooling the extruder motor sufficiently on hot days (yeah, we've got a heat spell now) and temps reached 41C.

So I strapped on a 5V but more powerful and larger CPU fan. Included files: Mounting bracket, grille and an extension plug (I've noticed people using cable ties, this extension plug will support M3 screws to secure the fan to the grille and bracket).

The mounting bracket angles the fan to col the side and top, doubling the area previously covered.

Needed:
4 x M3*8mm screws

For power I ran this to a make-shift 5V connection re-purposed from an old iPhone 5V1A plug and USB cable, which also supports another fan cooling the chassis (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:875471)

New size Multi ribbon sandals printed with my own PI-ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament.

Modelled aprox 251mm long and 103mm wide, Print http://palmiga.com/3dfiles/sandal_v4.11.pdf on A4 to compare with your foot and rescale part to your size
find tips on how to tie ribbon sandals: https://www.google.se/webhp?sourceid=chrome-instant&ion=1&espv=2&ie=UTF-8#q=how+to+tie+ribbon+sandals

Please also check out my unuiqe UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament.

Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this:

This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design:

•The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc.

http://rubber3dprinting.com/

author: airforce

description.text:
I moved replaced my extruder motor cooling fan with a larger one (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:941263) but since I had painstaking soldered it to the hot end fan before (and dreaded busting that now), I decided to cool the face of the extruder too.

But I didn't want the fan blocking access to the extruder, so... a swivel was added. Everything prints in 2 flat parts without support, secures to the top of the angled plate (below the hot end fan) with the fan screws and requires 1 additional M3*12mm screw (10mm would do) to hold the swivel in place. Fan swivels freely and is limited in two end positions.

A pencil grip for your 3d Printer! Make sure to resize to the width of your pencil. Additionally, rubbery materials can be used for best possible quality prints, but ABS or other non-ridged plastics work well. If you don't have any modeling software, I recommend using SketchUp and Blender to re-size and edit .stl's and other files. SketchUp: http://www.sketchup.com/
Blender: http://www.blender.org/ Have fun, and as always...
...Happy Printing =)
I wanted a pencil grip, and so I made a model for it, printed it and used it.  I printed it out of ABS, but I'd try using rubber as well.

title: Tantillus (Ultius) upper SLIDE-ON corners - Ultius upper corners

description.text:
I have made many new parts for my Tantillus, which I now call an Ultius, and had to remove the upper corners many, many timers.
It was really tedious having to do it in a certain sequence, so I quickly cut away pieces with my Dremel.

This is the printable corners, which you can put on even when all the rods are in place.

No special instructions. I always print with at least 3 or 4 perimeters (n times your nozzle size) and 0.2 layer height.
I have printed these both with 25% and 35% infill. Worked fine both ways.

title: Needle and filament - insulin pump cover

description.text:
Needle and filament is a family of insulin pump covers.
This work is a part of my degree dissertation, called "Ago e Filo", a thesis about the insulin microinfuser and the Diabetes.

The products have been made with the collaboration of +LAB http://www.thingiverse.com/piuLAB/about for a graduation in Design Engineering.

The method of shaping resambles the one used by Andreas Bastian: dip the flat print in hot water (>80c°) and wait few seconds. After heating remove the piece from water and put on the mounting template.
Bend the product on the template to obtain the correct geometry of the cover, keep it in position for cooling and next remove.

You should obtain a light cover for your micropump (Accuchek Combo or Animas Vibe)

MINIMAL COMBO: put the flat print of the cover in hot water and bend the sides once on the template. The cover has a clip for hanging on your clothes: to open it you have to form the little extension notched on the cover. You can bend it as you prefere, at your favourite and comfortable angle.

SKULL COMBO: is the most personalized product of the family. This cover was made for a single user, who was passionate about skulls. I will provide a file without the initial letters of his name.
To obtain the cover, the process is the same of the other products.
IMPORTANT!!: first put the flat print on the mounting template. Next, dip one side per time in the hot water and bend. It may result difficult the first time, the geometry is quite complex.
For the clip, you have to bend the relative part of the cover on this one, NOT around the template. (will upload detailed photoes).

ANIMAS ZOOM: for the Animas serie and the Minimal combo pause_print, I made a pause in the printing process. This feature has been made to put a shaped Fresnel lens into the cover, for the Animas model. The Minimal combo pause_print offers the possibility to change material to obtain a double colour cover or an overprint with a different material (my tests has been made with PLA Flex).

MEDTRONIC MINIMED: I have modified the clip previously made by two users: adding holes, you can insert a lace into the clip and ensure your pump to your belt.
This product must be intended as a replace part, not break your originalMedtronic clip!!!

Snap-together 3D printable gearset providing a reduction ratio of 27 to 1. Inspired by this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7379 and I used this script http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575 to generate the gears. The primary advantage of this design is that it uses only printable parts-- no fasteners, nuts or bolts.

• Print 3 of gears.stl, 2 of brace.stl and one each of the other parts. Do not print fullassembly.stl as that is just for the pretty render here on thingiverse.
  • Snap together.
  • There is no step 3
    UPDATE: Don't print this thing. Check out variations by tbuser http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9454 and makerblock http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9460 instead.

comments.text: I made one and it looks really cool!  Unfortunately the holes in the holders are way too big and consequently the gears move around and don't mesh right. (the braces also kinda slide in and sorta clamp it together and don't snap into the holes)  Maybe the tolerances on my printer are tighter than yours?  Also, it appears gear 3 has the teeth going the wrong way (the one that goes in the top and mates with the small gear beside it. (I'm not sure what the purpose of that second gear is anyway?)  I ended up printing a second gear 4 in it's place.
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text:
The TOM has much tighter tolerances than my cupcake, so I'm certain that will cause wobbliness for newer/better printers. This was originally intended as a replacement for the worm gear in my tank-bot design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8080http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... so the output needed to be at the bottom in order for the gears to not drag on the ground-- hence the second gear. The gear that's upside down can be flipped-- that's what the "top" part is for. It makes the input gear reversible. The input
&
amp; output gears should be oriented so that the square holes face outward. If I get some time I will try to re-do this thing in openscad so the tolerances can be more easily adjusted.
comments.author: tbuser

comments.text: FYI, I had the same problems as Tony, printing on a Prusa Mendel - the holes in the holder being too big resulting in the gears not meshing properly.

This lure is now for sale at Shapeways! It now has chambers for larger BBs and weight is offset for better action. Updates for thingiverse coming soon

Here's an awesome demonstration video of the lure by TallFishermanJ:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_yyEQYcagCY

This lure Prints in one piece and has multiple hinged segments that loosen up once the lure is bent back and forth a few times. This gives it a swimming action and it has internal chambers for adding metal bbs for rattles.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LDXZFjb0qd4&feature=youtu.be

I also experimented with a handful of other lure designs, you can see them here.

Printing:

This lure prints laying flat on its side, using support. Once printed, the support can be cut off and once the lure is bent at the joints, they should loosen up.

PLA at 0.1mm layer height with an 0.8mm shell thickness. The red lure pictured here was printed with a special Taulman PLA. I found this filament to be slightly more brittle and it helped the hinges loosen up better after printing, but standard PLA works too.

Metal bbs can be put in the chambers, and infill to weight the lure and add rattling effect. Exact rattle chamber diameter is 0.18in.

I used a standard 15% infill with internal bbs for rattles and the lure sank at a nice gentle rate, but you could probably experiment with different infill densities to alter the rate of sinking.

Hardware Used (about $12):
1.FISHING LURE SCREW EYES 25 PACK, (004) Closed Eye, 1/2" Overall Length, 5/16" Stem Length .050" Diameter
2.STAINLESS STEEL SPLIT RINGS 50 PACK, (004) Size 4
3.BLEEDING BAIT RED TREBLE HOOKS Size 6
4.3mm Dia Round Lead Split Shots Sinkers

comments.author: MSmith1022

comments.text: Would you consider doing a design which comes in five different separate & separable sections ?  This would require modified rotation parts that would be held in place with an axle, either printed or thick wire of about 1/8 inch, or maybe a 2mm screw which could be 'tapped' into an axle. This would also require all the rotation parts to have a hole  through which the axle would go, which can be incorporated in the design. It certainly would eliminate all the breakage problems, of which I've had a high (90%) failure rate, and would probably provide greater flexibility for the lure. That's probably because the 1st layer isn't sticking to the bed and instead curling up. It happens to me sometimes.
Maybe try adding glue + heating up your bed to help the 1st layer stick.
Also raise the bed so the gap between nozzle and bed is barely enough to get a sheet of paper tightly pass through.

title: bicycle luggage straps mounting hook for camper van table

description.text:
A what!? :-)

I made these hooks to mount biclycle luggage straps to the table of my camper van.
This way, you can easily fix any loose stuff to the table when driving.
The chances are small that you can find the exact same luggage straps i have,
but these hooks should be ok for other straps, as long as you can fit a M4 bolt through the end caps (i have drilled a 4mm hole in order to do so)

The hooks are made for a 18mm thick table top, but it can be used for anything between 12mm and 18mm when you remove some material with a hack saw.

That's a necklace. It looks like traffic light. In holes you should put leds. There is space for 4 leds: 2 red, 1 yellow and 1 green. At the down is hole for switch with 4 switches (one for every led). The necklace is powered by two AAA bateries (there is some space for springs). Traffic light is closed by tailgate. At the top is catch for neck-chain.

You can use leds two ways:

  1. To show how do you feel:
    up red & down red - very negative emotions
    down red - negative emotions
    down red & yellow - a bit negative emotions
    yellow - normal emotions
    yellow & green - a bit positive emotions
    yellow - positive emotions
  2. Choose which leds look best and switch them on.

If you have some more ideas how to use that, please share it with others in comment :D

1. Print it using supports.
  2. Delete all supports.
  3. Put leds in their holes and use hot glue to keep them there.
  4. Put switch in hole and use hot glue to keep it there.
  5. Put springs in theirs holes and use hot glue to keep them there.
  6. Connect all wires correct (I will upload plans soon).
  7. Put tailgate.
  8. Turn lights on, hang on your neck and look awesome.

Not much else to say here other than it's the Demoman!
Like all of my other TF2 stuff, this was originally uploaded to TF3DM by 3dregenerator, and I converted it to STL and got rid of the texture nonsense. http://tf3dm.com/user/3dregenerator

This is a rideable unicycle that can be printed on the Makerbot Replicator 2 or the Makerbot Replicator 5th Generation. I made it to enter the #LightItUp Thingiverse Challenge.

My initial plan was to have this printed and then add persistence of vision LED lights in the wheel (like this: http://goo.gl/Y62QZp), except with the Makerbot logo displayed. This has been my first experience with CAD/3D printing and I’ve been learning everything along the way, so I barely finished the CAD model in time! But if I win the 3D printer, I’ll be able to complete this project thoroughly and post videos of me riding the unicycle with Makerbot's logo glowing in the wheel. It would be like an investment for Makerbot.

If anybody else is interested in printing this, please send me a message and I’ll help you out and teach you to unicycle if need be.

Watch this video for a step by step visualization of the design: https://youtu.be/7nQ9h9WktBs

Let me know if you have any questions.

There are 24 different pieces that need to be printed, and everything can be printed in 6 print jobs on a Replicator 2.

To put the pieces together you need to use 0.25” nuts, bolts, and washers. That’s what all the holes are for in the design. You also need to add 0.25” steel balls for bearings (at 0:59 in the video you can see where they are placed--where the frame is clamped to the axle). The only other additional hardware is a tire tube and tire rubber. All available at any hardware store and bike shop.

The pedals do not use bearings. I used this concept: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16736

A fitting hole needs to be drilled for the air valve. I’d also recommend having an orbit sander and lubrication with you during assembly. And patience!

The wheel is 12 inches in diameter, which is on the small side, but it makes the persistence of vision lights work much better. Programming the Makerbot logo using a Spoke POV kit is my plan: goo.gl/Kx84Rg

Keep in mind that if I win the printer, I will be a rolling advertisement for Makerbot when I ride this to town every night! :)

title: Layer fan-ducts and mount for E3D V6

description.text:
I made a new design which is more compact, I recommend using this one instead: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1746358

I couldn't find a good layer fan duct and mount that could fit with a wade extruder on my Prusa i3, so I made a complete solution myself.

The fan I am using is a 5015S, you can find them on eBay for not too much money.
I printed everything with Colorfabb XT but ABS is good too. I wouldn't use PLA because of the low melt temperature.

The modius cam is a very common HD cam for FPV flying. This part is modeled to fit the contour of the top plate of the ZMR 250 or similar clones.

Video with this in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KPnZSV07AcQ

The Mobius wedge has a 16 degree top that gives the best compromise to capture great video of both fast and casual flying!

The part incorporates holes to allow the removal of the screws that hold the ZMR top plate on, this will allow you to semi permanently attache the wedge to the top plate ( I use double sided tape or VBH) and still allow you to take the top plate off. Lastly attach the mobius to the wedge with Velcro / dual lock / cable strap and your good to go!

The pictures show a damaged wedge as during testing I hit a steel pole head on! The part is very tough and was still perfectly usable.

Print in ABS or PLA .1 or .2 layer height, 2 outer shells 40% or less infill, 4 top and 4 bottom layers.

Flip the part so the top is printed face down so no support is required.
battery storage AAA

title: Frozen Snowflake Pendant
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed it as a present for a friend's daughter who just turn 4.
I've used light blue for the back piece and "glow in the dark" on the front piece.
Super simple to print. Nice present for a birthday party, of course Frozen themed ;)
The stl files have a size of about 50 mm. But as you can see on the pictures, I have printed a bigger version without problems.

On the files you can find a back piece without any text and an .ipt file for those who want to add their own text.

Print with your preferred colors. I have used a light blue and "glow in the dark". Once you have the front and the back parts, just glue them together with some cyanoacrylate glue like "super glue" (If you are using ABS as me). Then I used a small ring and a blue cord to finish it.
I used a silver paint marker to paint the text of the back piece.
